title: Movie Recommendations
text:
Introduction
As someone who loves rewatching movies or finding movies similar to ones I have seen before and loved, I wanted to see how chat gpt could cater movie recommendations based on knowing my specific music taste and what movies I liked before and why. For example, I don‚Äôt particularly love certain kinds of horror movies, but do enjoy psychological thrillers - like the movie Se7en but not unlike the movie Sinister. I will be using this example to see the movies Chat GPT gives me and why based on information. There are some movies I have seen and similarly liked and want to see if given this information they will be included in the suggested watch list I am asking for.
Prompt
I am interested in finding new movies to watch. I only like some horror movies, specifically the ones that are more so psychological thrillers and not paranormal jump scare based movies. for example, I loved the movie Se7en but did not like the movie Sinister. Can you help me find more psychological thrillers / horror movies based on this information?
Chat GPT Response
Absolutely! Since you liked Se7en (a slow-burn psychological thriller with dark, grounded crime elements) and disliked Sinister (a paranormal jump-scare horror), it sounds like you prefer:
Psychological tension over supernatural scares
Realistic human villains over ghosts/demons
Atmospheric dread and mind games over loud startles or gore
Here‚Äôs a list of movies that align with those preferences:
üß† Psychological Thrillers (Dark, Suspenseful, Grounded)
Zodiac (2007) ‚Äî From the same director as Se7en. A slow, unsettling hunt for the Zodiac Killer with a creeping sense of obsession and paranoia.
Prisoners (2013) ‚Äî A tense, morally complex thriller about two missing girls and the desperate hunt to find them.
Gone Girl (2014) ‚Äî A sharp psychological mystery about a missing wife and the media circus that follows.
Nightcrawler (2014) ‚Äî An unsettling character study about a morally void crime journalist chasing shocking footage.
The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011) ‚Äî A dark, stylish investigation of a decades-old murder with twisted family secrets.
ü™û Psychological Horror (Mind Games, Disturbing, Not Paranormal)
Black Swan (2010) ‚Äî A descent into obsession and psychosis set in the world of ballet; deeply unsettling and surreal.
The Babadook (2014) ‚Äî Although it has a ‚Äúmonster,‚Äù it‚Äôs really a metaphor for grief and depression; psychological more than paranormal.
The Others (2001) ‚Äî Minimal jump scares, mostly eerie atmosphere and psychological tension.
The Machinist (2004) ‚Äî A haunting portrayal of insomnia and guilt driving a man to the edge of sanity.
Jacob‚Äôs Ladder (1990) ‚Äî Disorienting and disturbing exploration of trauma and reality distortion.
ü©∏ Crime Thrillers with Psychological Depth
Silence of the Lambs (1991) ‚Äî A psychological cat-and-mouse between an FBI trainee and a brilliant but terrifying killer.
No Country for Old Men (2007) ‚Äî A tense and philosophical thriller about fate, morality, and a relentless killer.
Mystic River (2003) ‚Äî A dark, brooding drama about childhood trauma and its repercussions in adulthood.
Additional Prompt
For more information, a movie I liked as much as Se7en was Shutter Island, please give me another list based on that additional information
Chat GPT Response
Absolutely! Since you liked Se7en (a slow-burn psychological thriller with dark, grounded crime elements) and disliked Sinister (a paranormal jump-scare horror), it sounds like you prefer:
Psychological tension over supernatural scares
Realistic human villains over ghosts/demons
Atmospheric dread and mind games over loud startles or gore
Here‚Äôs a list of movies that align with those preferences:
üß† Psychological Thrillers (Dark, Suspenseful, Grounded)
Zodiac (2007) ‚Äî From the same director as Se7en. A slow, unsettling hunt for the Zodiac Killer with a creeping sense of obsession and paranoia.
Prisoners (2013) ‚Äî A tense, morally complex thriller about two missing girls and the desperate hunt to find them.
Gone Girl (2014) ‚Äî A sharp psychological mystery about a missing wife and the media circus that follows.
Nightcrawler (2014) ‚Äî An unsettling character study about a morally void crime journalist chasing shocking footage.
The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011) ‚Äî A dark, stylish investigation of a decades-old murder with twisted family secrets.
ü™û Psychological Horror (Mind Games, Disturbing, Not Paranormal)
Black Swan (2010) ‚Äî A descent into obsession and psychosis set in the world of ballet; deeply unsettling and surreal.
The Babadook (2014) ‚Äî Although it has a ‚Äúmonster,‚Äù it‚Äôs really a metaphor for grief and depression; psychological more than paranormal.
The Others (2001) ‚Äî Minimal jump scares, mostly eerie atmosphere and psychological tension.
The Machinist (2004) ‚Äî A haunting portrayal of insomnia and guilt driving a man to the edge of sanity.
Jacob‚Äôs Ladder (1990) ‚Äî Disorienting and disturbing exploration of trauma and reality distortion.
ü©∏ Crime Thrillers with Psychological Depth
Silence of the Lambs (1991) ‚Äî A psychological cat-and-mouse between an FBI trainee and a brilliant but terrifying killer.
No Country for Old Men (2007) ‚Äî A tense and philosophical thriller about fate, morality, and a relentless killer.
Mystic River (2003) ‚Äî A dark, brooding drama about childhood trauma and its repercussions in adulthood.
If you want, I can also make a short watchlist of lesser-known hidden gems in this same genre (movies you might not have heard of but are very much like Se7en in tone).
Would you like me to do that next?
You said: For more information, a movie I liked as much as Se7en was Shutter Island, please give me another list based on that additional information ChatGPT said:
Perfect ‚Äî that detail is super helpful.
Since you loved Shutter Island and Se7en, it‚Äôs clear your taste leans toward:
Psychological thrillers with mystery, twists, and unreliable perception
Dark tone, emotional depth, and strong character arcs
Grounded (realistic) settings rather than supernatural or jump-scare horror
So instead of supernatural horror, you want mind-bending psychological thrillers ‚Äî the kind that blur reality and drive characters toward obsession or madness.
üß† Reality-Bending Psychological Thrillers
The Sixth Sense (1999) ‚Äî A slow, emotional thriller about perception and grief, with a famous twist. (Less ‚Äúscary‚Äù than Sinister; much more psychological.)
The Prestige (2006) ‚Äî Two rival magicians in a dark, twisting battle of obsession and deception. Brilliant and suspenseful.
Fight Club (1999) ‚Äî From the same director as Se7en; explores identity, madness, and self-destruction with a major twist.
Memento (2000) ‚Äî A disorienting thriller told in reverse about a man with short-term memory loss trying to solve a murder.
Oldboy (2003) ‚Äî A dark, gripping Korean thriller about vengeance, imprisonment, and shocking secrets.
üïµÔ∏è‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è Dark Mystery / Detective Thrillers
Gone Girl (2014) ‚Äî A missing person case spirals into a psychological battle of manipulation and deceit.
Zodiac (2007) ‚Äî Slow-burning and obsessive; follows journalists and police chasing the elusive Zodiac Killer.
Prisoners (2013) ‚Äî A gripping and disturbing thriller about a desperate father hunting for his missing daughter.
The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2011) ‚Äî Dark, icy tone and a deeply layered murder mystery investigation.
ü™û Psychological Descent into Madness
Black Swan (2010) ‚Äî A haunting portrait of obsession, perfectionism, and mental unraveling.
The Machinist (2004) ‚Äî Stark and unsettling; follows a man consumed by guilt and insomnia until he loses his grip on reality.
Enemy (2013) ‚Äî Surreal and disturbing, about a man who discovers an exact double of himself; very Shutter Island-like in tone.
Conclusion
After looking through the responses (and having seen many of the ones listed and liking them) so overall do feel like AI did a good job capturing the essence of what I liked about the certain films I listed. I have not watched all of them, so will be later watching the ones I have not seen yet and continue to review and return.

title: A test post
text:
Read the following and see if you can answer the question:


There are three boxes in a stack. A pink one, a purple one and a green one. The pink one is in the middle of the stack with the purple below it. What is the color of the box on the bottom of the stack?

Most likely you answered purple‚Ä¶
But it is possible you first said green (don‚Äôt worry if you did it is quite a common response!)


It‚Äôs a verbal visual problem that requires some deliberation and most likely for us to create a visual image of a stack of boxes as a reasoning aid.
Notice also the complexity of the language used in the prompt to describe the scene. The use of natural language as opposed to a formal/logical calculus does hold the potential for ambiguity (multiple interpretations) and inexactness. However, it is the most normal/natural, efficient and broadly accessible way of communicating such information.
Notice 1. The use of anaphor or reference. - Three BOXES -> a pink/purple/green ONE as opposed to a pink box, a purple box and a green box. - The PINK ONE is in the middle ... the purple {BOX} below IT {the pink box}
We tend to try and avoid this kind of repetition to make our speech more coherent.

Although the description in language may not be entirely concise, there is no real ambiguity as to how the boxes can be arranged. It must be: | Box | Stack position | | ‚Äî | ‚Äî | | GREEN | top | | PINK | middle | | PURPLE | bottom |




GPT3.5 Turbo

Had some difficulties and answered green
Llama2 (chat 7B version)


Answered correctly (purple) and used some so-called chain-of-thought reasoning

Bing Chat (MS Co-pilot)
This LLM is GPT4 with some Microsoft specific tuning and RAG (search) additions.
It get‚Äôs it correct:

The color of the box on the bottom of the stack is purple. This is because the purple box is below the pink one, which is in the middle of the stack. Therefore, the purple box must be the lowest one. üü™

But when you follow up and ask it to create visual representation of the box arrangement

PROMPT: Can you create a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged?

It responds

RESPONSE: Sure, I‚Äôll try to create that. Here is a visual representation of how the boxes are arranged:

And uses DALL-E3 to create 4 different attempts at a visual representation:

NONE OF WHICH ARE CORRECT!!!

title: Cocktail Recipe
text:
Introduction
I am hosting a dinner party tonight and would like to see if Chat GPT can help me come up with a good cocktail that is unique and tasty to serve for a big group.
Prompt
I am hosting a dinner party tonight for around 20 people. It is a calm dinner with friends of mine and I want to think of a good cocktail that is universal enough to serve for a large group of people that most likely everyone will enjoy - not overwhelmingly sweet or bitter, but a classic cocktail. I do not want a standard cocktail like a margarita but something unique. Can you help me come up with something?
Response
ü•Ç Option 1 ‚Äî French 75 Punch
Profile: Light, crisp, bubbly, citrusy ‚Äî a celebratory crowd-pleaser Why it works: Universally appealing, refreshing, and festive without being sugary
Ingredients (for ~20 servings):
2 cups gin (London Dry like Tanqueray or Beefeater)
1¬Ω cups fresh lemon juice
1¬Ω cups simple syrup (1:1 sugar and water)
2 bottles chilled dry sparkling wine (like brut Champagne or cava)
Lemon wheels and sprigs of thyme for garnish
Instructions:
Chill all ingredients.
In a punch bowl, mix gin, lemon juice, and simple syrup with ice.
Just before serving, top with sparkling wine.
Garnish with lemon wheels and thyme.
Pro tip: Serve in coupe or flute glasses. Very elegant and easy to make ahead.
üçä Option 2 ‚Äî White Negroni Spritz
Profile: Bright, aromatic, slightly herbal ‚Äî more interesting than a standard spritz Why it works: Sophisticated but not bitter like a classic Negroni
Ingredients (for ~20 servings):
2 cups gin
2 cups Lillet Blanc (or Cocchi Americano)
1¬Ω cups Suze (gentian liqueur ‚Äî lightly bitter)
2 bottles prosecco or sparkling water (depending on strength preference)
Orange slices for garnish
Instructions:
Mix gin, Lillet, and Suze with ice in a pitcher or punch bowl.
Chill thoroughly.
Just before serving, top with prosecco (for a boozy spritz) or sparkling water (for lower-ABV).
Garnish with orange slices.
Pro tip: This looks beautiful served over ice in large wine glasses.
üçë Option 3 ‚Äî Peach Bourbon Smash (Lightened)
Profile: Fruity yet balanced, slightly herbal ‚Äî crowd-pleaser for whiskey skeptics Why it works: Approachable and unexpected; feels seasonal and cozy
Ingredients (for ~20 servings):
3 cups bourbon
2 cups peach pur√©e or nectar
1 cup fresh lemon juice
1 cup simple syrup
Handful of fresh mint leaves
Club soda (about 3‚Äì4 cups) to top
Instructions:
Muddle mint lightly in a punch bowl.
Add bourbon, peach, lemon juice, and simple syrup.
Stir with ice and chill.
Top with soda just before serving.
Garnish with mint sprigs and peach slices.
Pro tip: If peach isn‚Äôt in season, frozen slices or high-quality nectar work great.
Conclusion
I ended up making and trying each of these drinks with a few of my friends prior to the party, and ended up serving the French 75 and White Negroni spritz. These were well balanced drinks and great for a dinner party - and definitely much better than something I would have come up with!
